Bird Dog (musician)

Bird Dog is an Argentine musician, best known for his association with the influential rock band Ciro y los Persas. Early Life and Career

Bird Dog was born on February 12, 1955, in Buenos Aires, Argentina. Growing up in a musical family, he was exposed to a wide range of genres, from traditional Argentine folk to American rock and roll. He began playing the guitar at the age of 12 and soon formed his first band, Los Gatos Salvajes, with friends from his neighborhood. Breakthrough with Ciro y los Persas

In 1978, Bird Dog joined Ciro y los Persas, a rising rock band in Argentina, as a lead guitarist and backing vocalist. During his tenure with the band, they released three critically acclaimed albums, including "Ciudad de Pobres" (1980), "Viento y Marea" (1982), and "La Leyenda Continúa" (1985). Bird Dog's unique guitar style and harmonies were instrumental in shaping the band's distinctive sound. Notable Performances

One of Bird Dog's most notable performances with Ciro y los Persas was at the 1983 Quilmes Rock Festival, where they shared the stage with international acts such as The Police and The Clash.
